text: To anyone running ML models - how often do you retrain?

elements.text: To anyone running ML models - how often do you retrain?

text: Most likely that depends on the learning task and how much data you include in each model

elements.text: Most likely that depends on the learning task and how much data you include in each model

text: If you have a model with like 10 years of data , retraining every week I doubt would change too much unless you add huge bias to recent samples

elements.text: If you have a model with like 10 years of data , retraining every week I doubt would change too much unless you add huge bias to recent samples

text: Roughly once a month for me, but not sure there a generalised answer to this

elements.text: Roughly once a month for me, but not sure there a generalised answer to this

text: Updates normally tie in with ideas for new features

elements.text: Updates normally tie in with ideas for new features

text: Yeah, I retrain about once or twice a month. My training set is never older than past 4 months, but I hate retraining the model and re-deploying even though out of sample results are still as good as before. Maybe an unreasonable fear that things won't continue like they did on the older model

elements.text: Yeah, I retrain about once or twice a month. My training set is never older than past 4 months, but I hate retraining the model and re-deploying even though out of sample results are still as good as before. Maybe an unreasonable fear that things won't continue like they did on the older model

text: So you think any data older then 4 months old is useless?

elements.text: So you think any data older then 4 months old is useless?

text: Is this horses or dogs?

elements.text: Is this horses or dogs?

text: Nah, football. For my forecasting target and features, anything over 4-6 months has never added additional predictability. 4 months gives me 20-30,000 samples too which is sufficient to obtain good OOS performance. I put it down to change in dynamics as a competition progresses through its stages tbh. Im sure there are people for whom 10 years of data in football is useful tho, but their features must be way diff to mine

text: Ah fair enough, football not really my area. Interesting that there's no value in older data, maybe this suggests that the features aren't generalisable to stand the test of time. That's still a fairly small sample set I would say, again though I'm clueless when it comes to footie so this might be standard

text: I find that team/competition dynamics change a lot year on year, especially as players are bought/sold and new managers take over, so recency is quite critical for me (i.e. patterns from Premier League 10 years ago are relatively useless for me)

elements.text: I find that team/competition dynamics change a lot year on year, especially as players are bought/sold and new managers take over, so recency is quite critical for me (i.e. patterns from Premier League 10 years ago are relatively useless for me)

text: Yeah - automation there is the way to goooo. You're right, could do it daily, altho it's difficult to then spot if you've broken your model or it's just today's variance

text: Dumb question warning! Q: why would ML be any good at predicting crowd behaviour? Ie.a market? How can it predict participants? What would you use as inputs, fundamentals or technicals?

elements.text: Dumb question warning! Q: why would ML be any good at predicting crowd behaviour? Ie.a market? How can it predict participants? What would you use as inputs, fundamentals or technicals?

text: Have you heard of Bill Benter? Or any of the Hong Kong syndicates? They were using a form of regression (which is what ML is in some cases), to produce “true” prices and bet for value

elements.text: Have you heard of Bill Benter? Or any of the Hong Kong syndicates? They were using a form of regression (which is what ML is in some cases), to produce “true” prices and bet for value

text: But can you imagine how algorithms that allows you to make classifications or that could predict prices can help as an input to trading problems?

text: If not, this might not be the hobby for you…

text: Your question is “how would ML solve these specific problems”. You need to change the way you think. A better question is “ML is good at x, y and z. How can I use that to get an edge?”

elements.text: Your question is “how would ML solve these specific problems”. You need to change the way you think. A better question is “ML is good at x, y and z. How can I use that to get an edge?”

text: You are assuming you know the answer and just need to figure out the tools to help you prove it. Change it around: assume you don’t know anything and use the tools to ask questions. If that doesn’t appeal to you, this is definitely going to be very hard work and not very enjoyable.

elements.text: You are assuming you know the answer and just need to figure out the tools to help you prove it. Change it around: assume you don’t know anything and use the tools to ask questions. If that doesn’t appeal to you, this is definitely going to be very hard work and not very enjoyable.

text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> when you were playing around with WAP and stuff before how were you optimising to find whether a combination of those features were useful?

elements.text: when you were playing around with WAP and stuff before how were you optimising to find whether a combination of those features were useful?

text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> As an example, ML can be useful for detecting systemic bias in the crowd. So if the question being asked was "are soccer teams with large followings overbet?" you might use ML to build a model with fundamental features such as differences in home attendance, ground size, number of twitter followers, size of supporters club, shirt sales between two opponents. Or if you were wondering whether favourites or longshots are overbet / underbet in certain types of race, you could build a model using technical price data from the type of markets that you suspect could be prone to this.

elements.text: As an example, ML can be useful for detecting systemic bias in the crowd. So if the question being asked was "are soccer teams with large followings overbet?" you might use ML to build a model with fundamental features such as differences in home attendance, ground size, number of twitter followers, size of supporters club, shirt sales between two opponents. Or if you were wondering whether favourites or longshots are overbet / underbet in certain types of race, you could build a model using technical price data from the type of markets that you suspect could be prone to this.
